channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Norway Town and Its Pipeline to Jihad in Syria
item.description: After at least eight young men from a single neighborhood in Norway left for Syria, local officials were left pondering: Why it is that certain areas generate a disproportionate number of jihadists?
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A street in the district of Lisleby in Frederikstad, Norway, from which eight young men traveled to Syria to fight alongside the Islamic State and other groups.

item.title: Seeing a Cash Cow in Museums’ Precious Art
item.description: As budgets are pinched and business falters, public museums and companies across Europe are seeking to make ends meet by auctioning off artworks.
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:description: The Northampton Museum in Britain wanted to sell a 4,500-year-old limestone statue of Sekhemka to finance a remodeling.

item.title: Indonesia Frees 300 Men Found Enslaved on Island
item.description: Migrant fishermen who had been enslaved on trawlers for years rode those same vessels to freedom after a daring rescue from a remote island.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Fidel Castro Appears in Public for First Time in 14 Months
item.description: It was his first appearance since his brother, President Raúl Castro, and President Obama announced in December that the United States and Cuba would normalize diplomatic relations and loosen many of the economic restrictions Washington had placed on the island.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Kenyans Identify and Mourn Relatives Killed in Attack on University
item.description: Scores of families were waiting at the morgue on Saturday to identify relatives who died on Thursday when armed men belonging to the Shabab stormed a university campus and killed nearly 150 students.
item.dc:creator: ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:credit: Will Swanson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Salvation Army officer prayed on Saturday for relatives of those killed in Thursday’s attack at Garissa University College.

item.title: Diplomatic Memo: Outline of Iran Nuclear Deal Sounds Different From Each Side
item.description: A review of the statements released by the United States and Iran shows some significant divisions over the terms of the accord.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, and Federica Mogherini of the European Union.

item.title: Islamic State Seizes Palestinian Refugee Camp in Syria
item.description: Reports of killings and even beheadings were beginning to circulate, worsening what is already a longstanding humanitarian nightmare for the 18,000 residents of the Yarmouk refugee camp.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Apparent Saudi Strike Kills at Least Nine in Yemeni Family
item.description: The attack, part of the Saudi-led bombing campaign against the Houthi militants, may have been intended for a target a mile and a half away.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED ALI KALFOOD and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: News Analysis: After Shift in Nigeria, Entrenched-Party Rule Faces Test Elsewhere in Africa
item.description: An incumbent president steps down in a country with a history of military coups and rivalries, raising the possibility that it can happen elsewhere on the continent.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: Muhammadu Buhari’s victory in Nigeria's presidential election was hailed in Abuja last week.

item.title: Iran Will Allow Women in Sports Stadiums, Reversing a Much-Criticized Rule
item.description: Iran announced Saturday that women would be allowed to attend big sporting events, reversing a rule that had barred them from entering stadiums to watch matches attended by men.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Findings Reignite Debate on Claim of Jesus’ Bones
item.description: Aryeh Shimron, a geologist based in Jerusalem, believes he has established a common bond between two Christian relics: the James burial box and the Talpiot Tomb.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aryeh Shimron, a geologist based in Jerusalem, said the soil found on two sets of ancient burial boxes was a geochemical match.

item.title: Chinese Taxi Drivers Drink Pesticide in Beijing Protest
item.description: At least 10 men were hospitalized after they traveled to Beijing and drank pesticide to protest what they said was poor treatment by their companies.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Kamchatka, Home to Russian Version of Alaska Iditarod, Frets Over Growth
item.description: The remote Russian peninsula is caught between ambitious plans to develop untapped resources like gold and oil, and efforts to preserve its natural splendor.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The annual Beringia dog sled race, which was conceived 25 years ago as Russia’s answer to the Iditarod, passes through the remote Kamchatka peninsula.

item.title: World Briefing: Argentina: Britain Spied to Ensure Falklands Security, Report Says
item.description: Britain spied on Argentine military and political leaders to ensure the security of the Falkland Islands from 2006 to 2011, an Argentine television channel reported on Friday, citing intelligence documents provided by Edward J. Snowden.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: France: TV Reports on Hostage Taking Prompt Lawsuit and an Investigation
item.description: Families of the hostages held by a gunman who killed four people in a kosher supermarket in Paris in January are suing a French broadcaster, saying its live coverage endangered the hostages’ lives.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China Deports American Jailed on Spy Charges
item.description: Xue Feng, an American geologist imprisoned for more than seven years has been deported by China and has arrived home in Houston, a human rights organization said.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Nuclear Plant in Iranian Desert Emerges as Flash Point in Talks
item.description: Uncertainty remained over whether Fordo, once a secret site of Tehran’s nuclear program, will be converted into a peaceful research center or instead eventually aid Iran’s pursuit of an atom bomb.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: An Iran Nuclear Deal Built on Coffee, All-Nighters and Compromise
item.description: In hashing out one of the hardest-to-negotiate arms control agreements in history, Iran and the United States took a simple approach: stay in the same hotel room until they figure out how to get along.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry with Wendy Sherman, the leader of the American negotiating team, in Switzerland on Thursday.

item.title: A U.S. Concession to Reality in the Battle Against Islamic State
item.description: In the battle to retake Tikrit, the Iraqi military served as a go-between for two global adversaries that did not want to publicly acknowledge that they were working together.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Praying for a slain relative at the platform on the Tigris River where Islamic State fighters are believed to have killed hundreds of Iraqi soldiers last June.

item.title: Antitrust and Other Inquiries in Europe Target U.S. Tech Giants
item.description: New developments offer the latest sign that American tech giants face intensifying scrutiny in Europe that could curb their profits in the region and affect how they operate around the world.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: A commuter wearing Beats headphones in New York. European concerns focus on whether Apple may try to persuade labels to favor its new streaming service over those of rivals.
